title.narrative: Provision of emergency, life-saving WASH assistance to vulnerable populations affected by the Mosul conflict

description.narrative: Ongoing military operations to retake Mosul have caused large-scale displacements and massive destructions to the city infrastructures, thus resulting in a major humanitarian crisis. To date, it is estimated that 400,000 people remain in Western neighborhoods of Mosul with very limited access to humanitarian assistance. In addition, more than 235,700 people have fled from west Mosul and are currently displaced in camps and emergency sites, with the majority being located in the southern corridor of Mosul. Provision of drinking water is one of the key priorities, in both areas. Humanitarian actors’ capacity in displacement sites are currently overstretched and drinking water resources are scarce. In Mosul city itself, access to safe drinking water is also urgently needed as water service provision have been almost entirely disrupted by the ongoing offensive, and people are currently relying on unsafe sources of water. SI is already actively participating in the WaSH response through the installation of an emergency surface water treatment station in Hamam Al Alil (HAA), which has an estimated production capacity of 900m3 per day. This water is currently being made available to humanitarian actors active in the southern corridor (mainly Oxfam and NRC) and in West Mosul (SI and ACF in the short run). Through the proposed intervention, SI together with NRC will scale up the current response through the following: 1) By continuing to operate the existing SWAT in HAA until end of August (when other more durable water provision system will be rehabilitated), therefore providing water with a capacity to cover 120,000 people (delivered through SI and other humanitarian actors) 2) By setting up another SWAT system, in partnership with NRC, closer to Western Mosul (Abu Saif) where needs are expected to grow with newly areas becoming accessible and to reduce the time and costs for transportation of water towards West Mosul 3) By providing emergency WaSH assistance in Western Mosul, including distribution of drinking water via water trucking (using the water produced in the SWAT) for an estimated 30,000 people (covering two neighborhoods), distribution of hygiene kits, hygiene messages dissemination. The proposed approach is in line with both the IHPF and the WaSH cluster strategic priorities 1 amp 2. SI will continue to ensure a close coordination with all involved stakeholders to deliver a rapid, efficient and targeted response, guaranteeing equal access to water and sanitation for all women, girls, boys and men in the targeted project locations through the most- cost-effective solutions. Therefore, SI will rely in its globally demonstrated WASH expertise and on its presence in the area and its on-going programmes.
